Award.AwardTitle: A new approach to equatorial inertial instability
Award.AbstractNarration:
By undertaking this investigation of equatorial inertial instability the understanding of the role that the instability plays in the destabilization and equilibration of ocean currents in equatorial regions will be significantly improved. New theories will be developed to help in improving our understanding of inertial instability in the near-equatorial regions. Results obtained through this research can have an important impact on the future development of ocean models. Small-scale, near-equatorial instabilities are not resolved in ocean models, but their role in developing and maintaining large-scale currents is very important. By studying these instabilities, their effects can be predicted and, hence, be parameterized in ocean models. Improvement in ocean modeling can have important impact on climate research because of the essential role that the equatorial ocean plays in controlling the climate.

A comprehensive study of symmetric instability of parallel shear flows for the equatorial beta-plane will be conducted by incorporating the full Coriolis force. Results will be contrasted with the commonly used traditional beta-plane approximation. The potentially extremely rapid downward mixing resulting from the instability with the 'true' Coriolis force suggests that the traditional approximation is a very poor one. Under terrestrian circumstances the horizontal scales are disturbingly small and therefore never resolved in global ocean circulation models. The correct redistribution of momentum, downward buoyancy flux and energy dissipation are thus not accurately accounted for. The proposed research will help in determining the correct parameterizations of these processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this research we have investigated the character of near-equatorial inertial instability of oceanic currents
incorporating the full Coriolis force instead of the `traditional’ dynamics where the horizontal components of Earth’s rotation vector is neglected. Inertial instability is simply so called `centrifugal instability’ which is easily observed at home  when one tries to stir up a vortex in the middle of a large bucket of water: this is impossible because of the instability which leads to chaotic turbulent motions.  In a teacup however the walls prevent the instability and the fluid swirls smoothly with just slow changes until all motions cease.

Inertial instability is the term used for centrifugal instability when for example a large bucket of water is placed on a rotating turntable. Then when the water rotates with the table a smooth swirl vortex can be created  by stirring in the direction of the rotation of the table but not when stirred against the rotation. This implies that near the equator on our rotating planet a westward flowing current should be susceptible to the instability if the zonal velocity drops a mere 1.5 cm/s over a depth of  100 meters, provided the water is not density stratified (a well mixed upper layer). This vertical shear is the cause of the instability whereas with the traditional approximation it is associated with horizontal (north-south) shear.

With numerical simulations and through simple theory we have shown that when the full Coriolis force is taken into account  the instability takes a distinctly vertical character when there is no stratification: up and down motions as opposed to horizontal motions in the traditional dynamics. At high  Reynolds numbers (low viscosity) the horizontal scales can become very small and may pose problems in ocean general circulation models unless very high resolutions are used. Further with the full Coriolis force  the development can be very fast (hours) unlike the slow development typically found when the traditional
approximation is made. Finally, under the assumption of zonal symmetry—no variations in the along flow direction—the new current that emerges from the turbulent and chaotic phase triggered by the instability can be predicted with high precision.  Whether it is imperative to consider the full Coriolis force also when the upper ocean is stratified is currently being investigated.  

Results obtained through the research may  be important for the future development of ocean models. Small-scale, near-equatorial
instabilities are usually not resolved in ocean models, but their role in developing and maintaining large-scale currents is very important. By studying these instabilities, we can predict their effects and  parameterize these in ocean models. Improvement in ocean modeling can have important impact on climate research because of the essential role that the equatorial ocean plays in controlling the climate.
